div.p:
I had a great
mind to have written to you by Mr. Brinkley
but as my father wrote to Dr. Brinkley I
thought a letter from me would be quite
superfluous. However William assures
me, - & I am willing enough to believe him, -
that you will like to hear from me. -

We are truly obliged to you and
Dr. Brinkley for sparing your son to us even
for this short visit, and all we hope is that
he feels as well disposed to repeat his visit
as we are to desire them - His agreeable man-
ners manners and that benevolent expression of coun
tenance countenance to which both by father's & mother's
side he has an hereditary right first pre-
-possessed prepossessed us in his favor and certainly
made us feel additional interest in his
conversation and pleasure in every fresh
instance & proof of his abilities & information

- Allow me to say, that the more he mix-
es mixes
both in the company both of men of
the world as they are called & of persons
of science & literature, the more he measures
himself with others the more confidence
he must acquire in himself from compa-
-rison comparison - so that even his extreme diffidence

William
with his love
to John insists
upon my
telling him
that he has
completely
conquered
the laziness
of which he
complained
when they
were here

will sooner or later be convinced that all which
he now seems to think it it
worth while worthwhile
for others to attend to or for himself to take
the time & trouble to utter is fifty times better
worth saying and hearing than what the
most forward & talkative exhibitors in
general company announce with great
emphasis and self complacency. I venture
to say this much because either my own
vanity or your sons kindness of manner
towards me has persuaded me that I
have some share of his esteem & that it
least he believes I would not say what I
do not think - We all feel sincerely in-
terested interested for him not only on yours & his
fathers account but on his own - I
must add my dear Mrs. Brinkley that
for my own selfish part I felt peculiarly
obliged & gratified by the ease & cordiality
with which he conversed with me, instead
of making me painfully sensible of the
repulsive power or name of an authoress

I well know how much you
are interested for your young friend
Mr. Robinson This is likely referring to Thomas Romney Robinson, another Irish astronomer, & therefore I wish I could
convey to you an idea of the strong im-
=pression impression which he has been left in this family
especially on my father's mind, of his
superior talents, extensive, various, accurate

knowledge & of his uncommon energy & per-
-severance perseverence - I cannot do justice to my fathers
eloquence on this subject- It must be heard
to be felt & to carry with it that full con-
viction conviction of truth & of esteem, bothwhich
I am well aware are necssary to prevent
praise from hurting Mr. Robinsons proud
feelings -

We all felt much obliged to him for the
readiness with which he opened & commu-
nicated communicated his rich stores of knowledge -
the more so, as it was evidently done with
=out without ostentation - for our sakes - not for his
own - We all join in one common wish
that we could remember one hundredth
part of what at the moment we heard
it we flattered ourselves we should never
forget. I believe this is the general feeling
of the whole family - from little Francis
(to whom he was peculiarly kind) up to
my father in whom it appears (for good
reasons) to be the strongest -

My father has not been nearly so well
since these young friends left him - Their
conversation was a powerful & most agree-
able agreeable cordial & stimulus to him & certainly
he has felt the loss of it much - And we have
felt its power more since it was withdrawn
than ever whilst it operated - It any thing

were necessary to increase our regret for
their departure this would do it in the strong
est strongest manner - and We hope this will be
an additional motive to their good nature
to repeat the cordial on the first possible
occasion -

Mrs. Edgeworth and my father are quite
convinced that you & Dr. Brinkley wish
in good earnest to come to Edgeworths Town -
So am I - I am of easy faith in believing what
I warmly wish - So pray don't disappoint
or counter -convince us that we flattered our selves ourselves
- and bring Miss Brinkley with you & make
us as well acquainted with her & with her
elder brother as we are with Mr. J. Brinkley
- whom I now look upon (am I mistaken?)
quite as a family friend - William sends
his love - He has heartily felt the loss of his
morning = noon & night companions
but I fancy his maps have not been
the worse for this
div.closer:
Believe me my dear Mrs. Brinkley
with true gratitude for that affectionate
partiality which I know you feel for me
your obliged
Maria Edgeworth
1816
